did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle: The Records of a General Store at Fredericks Hall, Louisa County, Virginia
did.physdesc: This collection consists of microfilm of four bound manuscript volumes.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Records of a General Story at Fredericks Hall, Louisa County, Virginia, Accession #4201, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was deposited for historical reference on March 26, 1953, by Mrs. E.H. Poindexter, Fredericks Hall, Louisa County, Virginia, through Mr. R.N. Davidson of Rhoadesville, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of microfilm of four bound manuscript volumes, recording the transactions of patrons of a general store located at Fredericks Hall, Louisa County, Virginia. The first two volumes are account ledgers which cover the years 1735-1738, and 1756. The other two volumes are daybooks which contain entries for April 1845-December 1848 and February 1855-December 1859.
The two ledgers (1735-1738 and 1756) in this collection are from a general store located in Louisa County, Virginia, and record the transactions of a store's patrons.

Louis County was not officially established until 1742, a year falling between the dates of these ledgers. Thus, in comparison to the "older" counties to the east, this region was not far removed in time from being the "frontier." Besides the few families that may have kept various written records, there were few institutions besides the court house to keep written records that would document daily life of the people in the area. Thus, the general store, being one of the centers of trade, created records of significant historical value. The first census of the county would not be taken until 1790, and that census, as well as the 1800 census, would later by destroyed in the War of 1812. As many of these ledgers may not appear in extant court records or other documents, much of the information in these volumes is unique.

Not only do the accounts give the names of many of the residents, and furnish information about what supplies the patrons purchased, but they show how - and when - the accounts were settles. Out of necessity, the general store fulfilled many of the functions of a banking institution, extending credit to patrons to make purchases and arranging for excahnges of credit among the patrons to settle debts. Cash was scarce, and often patrons settled their accounts in produce, or with returned merchandise. It is also interesting to note that credit was given to a few women and blacks, as well as men, and in the 1756 ledger, the occasional notes giving the kinship of some patrons, or their occupations.

The first of the two ledgers contains entries fro the years 1735-1738. This volume was apparently a successor to an earlier volume, as many of the accounts begin with the entry, "By ballance due brought from [ledger] A folio ___." And it appears that ownership of the store changed hands in April 1738, as many of the accounts at that time are closed with the statement, "Ballance due to Thomas Partridge," [the new owner].

This volume is foliated at the upper left corner of the debit (Dr) pages. A number of pages, however, are misssing, and several numbers are repeated, as noted below. In the course of preparing the index which follows, later entries yielded the names of the patrons for two of the credit pages for which the debit pags are missing. Page 4 (R) is the credit portion of the accoutn of Cornelius Dabney, and page 167 (R), for Evan Mitchell.

Foliation, 1735-1738
1-4(L) Missing
4(R)-166(L)
166(R)-167(L) Missing
167(R)-185
185-193
193-232
[233 omitted in foliation]
234-236(L)
236(R)-248(L) Missing
248(R)-266
[266A]
267-325
326-327 Blank
328 "Negroes"
Miscellaneous loose receipts

The second of the two ledgers contains entries for the year 1756, and apparently was the third ledger in a series of subsequent to the series in which the volume for 1735-1738 was a part. Many of the accounts begin with the entry, "To ballance his acct. [from] Ledger B folio___," and are closed with the statement, "To ballance carried to his credit [in] Ledger D." As in the case of the first volume, the pages are foliated in the upper left corners of the Debit (Dr) pages, and a number of pages are missing, as noted below. Other pages have had portions removed.

Unlike the first volume, this ledger occasionally notes the family relationships or occupations of the patrons, and the locality or the county in which the patrons resided (see index which follows). The inclusion of entries for the counties of Caroline, Orange, Halifax, Albermarle (or "Rockfish") and Spotsylvania, is an indication that a number of the patrons were not "local" residents, but merely passed through Louisa County on their way to Richmond, Williamsburg, etc.

Foliation, 1756
1-4(L) Missing
4(R)-32
32[A]
33-58(L)
58(R)-61(L)
61(R)-137(L)
137(R)-138(L)
138(R)-195(L)
195(R)-[end] Missing
Loose Pages:
1754-1756, Debit account: Charles Gregory to Charles Smith
1757: Account of Henry Gilbert

The two daybooks (1845 April-1848 December, and 1855 February-1859 December) in this collection reveal that the location of the store was at Fredericks Hall. Unlike the two ledgers, which contain both debits and credits recorded under individual accounts of the patrons, these volumes were a part of a more sophisticated system. Daily transactions are recorded chronologically, rather than directly in the patron's account. Periodically, the propietor entered the sum of the transactions for each patron in a separate account ledger (not present in the collection) and noted the page number of that account to the left of the daybook entry.
Given the large number of individual entries in these volumes, and the fact that census records for the period covered by the daybooks are extant, indexes to these were not prepared.

Interesting comparisons can be made between the types of merchandise purchased as recorded in these daybooks and the types of merchandise that was purchased a century earlier, as recorded in the two ledgers.

The first of the two daybooks contains chronological entries from April 1845 to December 1848. The volume is paginated in the upper outside corner of each page. As noted below, a number of pages are missing, and some page numbers are repeated. Portions of other pages have been torn out. This volume has suffered futher damage as a result of having been shot with a shotgun through both the front and back covers.

The second of the two daybooks contains chronological entries from February 1855 to December 1859. Blank pages following the daybook entries were later used for excercises in French (not filmed) and to record copies of three letters. The volume is paginated in the upper outside corner of each page. As noted below, a few pages are missing, and a portion of page 137-138 has been torn out.

Pagination, 1855-1859
1-154
155-156 Missing
157-176
176[A]
177-195
196-197
198-227
228-229 Missing
230- 264
"French Excercises" (not filmed)
Copies of Letters: 1876 Oct 25, Waller Overton Harris to his brother, Fred
1876 Nov 8, Waller Overton Harris to his sister, Flora
1876 Nov 15, Waller Overton Harris to his brother, John
